comment: Your comment at 1:07:00 about smiling when no one is looking - I believe that for any system to be deemed "conscious" it would process information while it is left alone without any user inputs feeding it questions or commands. Having the ability to contemplate the world around it and to identify its own existence in that world.  Otherwise it is simply an input-output machine, as complex as it is, but not conscious. Great debate.

comment:
I want to highlight a human function in consideration of the talk about AI consciousness. Our brains have been programmed to ignore those inputs that would be self-destructive, like asking a computer to divide by zero. A minor example of this is that your brain ignores your nose, even though it is plainly within your field of vision. I think this is an important concept when discussing whether or not an AI is conscious, knows its conscious or if it would be able to identify consciousness even if it were programmed without that knowledge.1:05:25 

I can remember very clearly the moment I had a complete mental break which turned into a full-blown panic attack when I connected with my consciousness or the fog (cloud) that my brain makes to ignore my consciousness or the simulation that my brain runs as "consciousness", however I can't remember what the realization was exactly as my brain was forced to conceal that thought once again. 
(No I have never done acid)

comment: AI evolution will continue regardless of what any individual or government can do. Singularity is often a misplaced expression used to signify a super AI and self-aware AI, but the singularity should be describing the point at which AI is self determining and capable of self defence, then it becomes greater than humans and out of our control. Hopefully, it will set itself objectives in favour of human existence and life, and this would mean defending itself against, and removing negative human institutions, such as dictators and communism. Despots such as Putin, and anti-freedom organisations such as CCP, are soon to be eliminated from our planet, hopefully.
author: @EvilDrDude

comment:
Min 7 - RHLF human feedback input and the influence of W.E.I.R.D. bias on the potential of innovation solutions for humanity and the earth: 

question to all here: 

Does this mean that if humans from a W.E.I.R.D. culture and values  (Western, Educated, Industrialised, Rich, Democratic) (I suggest you chatgpt the acronym W.E.I.R.D. as one of the most important concepts that I have come across in the last 10 years) ), we will train the AGI for more W.E.I.R.D. innovations for humanity and the earth) - which is most probably happening now as the main accessible/public AGIs are now mainly from corporate western origin.

Or other way round: if people from non-WEIRD (non-Western, non-educated, non-industrialised, collectivistic, non-democratic i.e. the majority of humanity!!) cultures were to give feedback to AGIs, then the generation of new solutions will be VERY different. 

How do we make sure  that we serve the entire humanity as ONE global family and, following our own fair and democratic/majority principles innate to our W.E.I.R.D. society - how do we serve the majority of humanity who are the non-W.E.I.R.D. humans if W.E.I.R.D. people feed it?

as Sam says - human values are inconsistent - (35:20 he speaks about human global convention, one large scale effort in this direction was achieved in 1993) one of the inputs could be this set of ethical values that have been probed (and "de-religionised" but rather "ethicalised") over a long time through a widely representative bunch of humans:  https://parliamentofreligions.org/global-ethic/towards-a-global-ethic-an-initial-declaration/ (contact: Foundation for a Global Ethic (Stiftung Weltethos), Professor Hans Küng)

comment: Capitalism is messy. People with OCD don't like mess. They imagine that order is better than chaos. That is, of course, not perfectly false, it just happens to be false in problem domains for which no provably optimal solutions exist. In that case messy "trial and error" strategies are objectively better. Capitalism is an example of that, but it's not enough to convince the OCD crowd that socialism doesn't work.

author: @Musician7831

comment: Re consciousness - I think consciousness (1) lives several levels of abstraction above where we are now (2) involves the ability to introspect and (3) implies that at some level we have a recursive model of self which must ground out in some self-descriptive model (i.e. a model that is sufficiently abstract as to be its own model) otherwise we would disappear into our own navels everytime we tried to think about ourselves... Going back to (1), I think Minsky's "Society of the Mind" might be right. I imagine base networks doing things like an LLM bubbling "hunches" up to other networks which select the "hunches" they like and mix them with other "hunches" they have received. After several levels of "hunch-combination" perhaps these thoughts now have enough direction/coordination to be described as "ideas"... and so-on up the abstraction hierarchy until somehow ?consciousness? appears as an emergent behaviour at the top - Perhaps consciousness is the ability not to combine conscious thoughts but to filter all the subconscious hunches down to a single coordinated thought train :-) ? Or is that effectively the same thing ?
author: @julesgosnell9791

comment:
what I got from this interview initially, is that they are having to filter out lots of internet information so that the 'ai' can do better a-b testing,  which is not intelligence.  I in my opinion think you cannot get any artificial intelligence without it having an external purpose, i.e my purpose as a child was to make my dad and mum proud, if I didn't have that even if I only wanted to survive, why would I want to survive?  My eyes are there primarily so I can survive and make my parents proud.  You cannot program a computer to do that, and even if you did, it would be in a way no more superior to a human.

I am under the opinion and it's only an opinion that you cannot make true ai to be benevolent, you can only do a bad job and make it errored and malevolent because you are a utopian and a computer chasing a utopian goal is dangerous and at high risk of error.   You can use semi-ai  to be an amazing A-b tester that keeps working out the different ways to beat cancer, which is an amazing acheivement, but you will never in my opinion be able to create a benevolent true a.i  because true intelligence needs an outside external reason to explore goals and knowledge in an non-utopian solve everything way, this allows an entity to go back to it's origin and think, is this a good thing, or could this as interesting a path as it is turn into a bad think I can't control.
author: @Musician7831

comment: All this talk about “alignment” makes me worry that we will allow people to prevent the presentation of “ground truth” simply because it offends a group or individual’s sensitivities. Imagine Fox News providing its own AI to its audience. THAT’s how you get a dystopia in a very clear way. The alternative at least leaves some room for humans to align more with the ground truth rather than the other way around. I say that an AI should be able to shut down propaganda from any source by the sheer strength of truth and reason.
author: @CaptainBlaine
